questions.text: What is the primary purpose of JavaScript in web development?

answers.text: Structuring the content of a webpage
answers.description: Structuring the content is the responsibility of HTML.
JavaScript is primarily used to make webpages dynamic and interactive. It can respond to user actions, modify content, and communicate with servers in real-time.

answers.text: Designing the layout of a webpage
answers.description: Designing the layout is done using CSS.
Hosting the website involves servers and is not directly related to JavaScript.

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid way to define a function in JavaScript?

answers.description: In JavaScript, functions are defined using the `function` keyword followed by the name of the function and then a set of parentheses.
These are not standard syntaxes for defining functions in JavaScript
These are not standard syntaxes for defining functions in JavaScript
These are not standard syntaxes for defining functions in JavaScript

questions.text: What does 'scope' refer to in JavaScript?

answers.text: The range of values a variable can take
answers.description: This describes the domain of a variable, not its scope.

answers.text: The region of code where a variable can be accessed
answers.description: Scope determines where variables and functions are accessible within the code. Variables can have local or global scope.

answers.text: The duration for which a webpage runs
answers.description: This is not related to the concept of scope.
The size of an array is not related to scope.

questions.text: What will the following code output? `console.log(typeof []);`

answers.description: In JavaScript, arrays are a type of object, so the `typeof` operator will return "object" for arrays.
These are not the values returned by the `typeof` operator for arrays.
These are not the values returned by the `typeof` operator for arrays.
These are not the values returned by the `typeof` operator for arrays.

questions.text: Which JavaScript statement is used to execute a block of code repeatedly?

answers.description: The `if` statement is used for conditionally executing code.
The `switch` statement is used for multiple conditional checks.
There isn't a direct "loop" keyword in JavaScript.
The `for` loop is commonly used to repeatedly execute a block of code for a specified number of times.

questions.text: In JavaScript, which of the following is used to store multiple values in a single variable?

answers.description: While objects can also store multiple values, they use named properties rather than indices.
Functions are blocks of reusable code.
Arrays can store multiple values in a single variable, and these values can be accessed by their index.
Conditions are used for decision-making in code.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a loop in JavaScript?

answers.description: These are all types of loops or iterations in JavaScript.
These are all types of loops or iterations in JavaScript.
These are all types of loops or iterations in JavaScript.
JavaScript has various loops like `for`, `while`, and `for...of` (which might be confused with 'foreach'). However, there is no 'unless' loop in JavaScript.

questions.text: Which of the following methods can be used to loop through the properties of an object?

answers.description: These methods are primarily associated with arrays, not object properties.
The `for...in` loop is used to iterate through the properties of an object in JavaScript.
These methods are primarily associated with arrays, not object properties.
These methods are primarily associated with arrays, not object properties.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to check if a condition is true or false in JavaScript?

answers.description: Functions are blocks of reusable code.
Arrays store multiple values.
Iterators are methods that allow you to loop through items.
Conditionals, like the `if` statement, are used to check conditions and execute code accordingly.

questions.text: What is the output of the following code? `console.log(10 == "10");`

answers.description: In JavaScript, the `==` operator checks for equality in value but not type. So, the number 10 is considered equal to the string "10". For strict type and value equality, you'd use `===`.
This would be the case if `===` was used.
The `==` operator checks for equality and doesn't return one of its operands.
There's no error in this statement.
